Project Description  The Project will strengthen the pro-poor public elementary school 
system in Sindh Province in Pakistan through rehabilitation and 
upgrading  of  classes  1-5  primary  schools  to  classes  1-8 
elementary schools to ensure full provincial coverage for eligible 
students  in  rural  areas.  The  Project  will  employ  community 
mobilization to increase enrollments and reduce dropouts. It will 
support improvement programs to bolster attendance including 
preprimary  classes,  life-skills  training  and  school  development 
fund  awards  for  school  performance  in  3,400  existing  and 
upgraded elementary schools. The Project will build capacity at 
the  school-community,  subdistrict,  district,  and  provincial 
education offices to better plan, manage, budget, and monitor 
school  performance,  especially  attendance,  and  to  strengthen 
local decision making and accountability. 
   
Rationale  Sindh Province wants to invest in its children so that they become 
good, productive citizens who will participate in the economy and 
the society. A province-wide public elementary school system will 
ensure a quality public good equitably provided through targeting 
special groups to help reduce poverty. The Provincial Education 
Department  will  encourage  a  more  open  market  for  basic 
educational  services  by  providing  information  on  school 
performance and ensuring universal access, especially to those 
groups  least  able  to  afford  elementary  education.  The  Sindh 
Government is aware that economic development and poverty 
reduction  are  dependent  on  a  strong  foundation  of  basic 
education  and  adult  literacy  in  the  population.  The  Millennium 
Goals  suggest  that,  unless  students  acquire  about  8  years  of 
education, the numerous benefits of education may be lost.  
   
Objectives and Scope  The objective of the Project is to increase access to a pro-poor 
decentralized public elementary school system with 60% of the 
beneficiaries being the rural poor coming from the lowest 40% 
income distribution. Increased access to elementary education will 
raise retention rates, especially for girls and the rural poor, leading 
to greater numbers continuing on to further schooling and to wider 
job  opportunities  for  those  leaving  school  after  class  8.  The 
Project  will  raise  the  quality  of  elementary  education  through 
provision  of  stipends,  scholarships,  free  textbooks,  teacher 
training, and incentives to enable students to benefit from quality 
education.  It  will  strengthen  decentralized  management  at  the 
provincial,  district,  and  subdistrict  levels.  It  will  strengthen  the 
public school system to more equitably provide public goods to 
females  and  the  poor  in  the  newly  decentralized  education

Risks and Assumptions  There are two project risks. The first has to do with the recurrent 
costs needed for sustainability, especially after project completion. 
Upgrading  over  1,200  schools  to  full  elementary  schools  will 
require  additional  staff  based  on  a  decision  from  the  Sindh 
Finance Department to create and then fill sanctioned posts by the 
end of the Project. Teacher scholarships, incentives, and flexible 
contracting  will  help  meet  recruitment  targets.  The  Project  will 
provide incremental recurrent costs to cover the hiring of teachers 
during project implementation when delays in appointments might 
affect progress. Covenants include assurances that Government 
will take decisions to appoint adequate numbers of teachers for 
project schools before project completion. The sustainability of 
stipends  and  free  textbooks  is  based  on  assurances  that  the 
Government will fund these interventions for girls in classes 6-8 
after project completion. 
 
The  second  project  risk  has  to  do  with  Pakistan’s  newly 
decentralized  system  of  power  sharing.  The  plan  delegates 
decision  making  to  the  local  level  so  that  stakeholders  take 
responsibility  for  the  proper  functioning  of  schools.  As 
decentralization is new, it is still unproven. The Project will provide 
funds  for  continuous  training  of  provincial,  district,  and  local 
education staff to supplement ongoing efforts by the Government. 
The  Project  also  provides  incentives  in  the  form  of  innovative 
programs for communities and local administrators to choose from 
in assuming responsibility for the education of children in each 
community. Other ADB and funding agency adjustment credits 
and policy reform program loans that support decentralization will 
also ensure that adequate funds are provided to the districts.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan to 
the Islamic Republic of Pakistan for the Decentralized Elementary Education Project (Sindh). 
 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
 
2.  For years, Pakistan has struggled to achieve universal primary education (classes 1-5) 
especially in rural areas and for females. Throughout the 1990s, gross enrollment rates for 
primary schooling increased from about 64% to 72%, while during the same period literacy rates 
for those over age 10 years increased from about 34% to 45%. Enrollments in rural areas have 
increased from 30% to 40%, while the gender gap has narrowed in favor of girls from about 40% 
to  30%  during  the  same  period.  These  accomplishments  have  taken  place  while  overall 
population growth has expanded at about 2% per annum, implying that enrollment growth has 
averaged almost 3% per year. In general, Pakistan made progress in spite of the Asian Crisis, 
which limited growth in the economy and accompanying curtailment of resources for education. 
This was in part due specifically to the externally assisted Social Action Program (SAP) and 
accompanying  investment  projects  implemented  especially  in  the  early  1990s  to  upgrade 
schools.1  
 
3.  The province of Sindh accounts for about 25% of the total class 1-8 elementary school-
aged children in Pakistan. Primary school enrollments in Sindh mirror those for the nation, as 
about 67% of eligible students in Sindh attended classes 1-5 primary schools in 2000. However, 
only 38% of 12-14 year olds in Sindh who graduated from primary schools progress to classes 6-
8. This number is below the national average and, more importantly, has been dropping over the 
past 8 years from about 50% to 38% due to lack of expansion to accommodate larger cohorts of 
primary school graduates. Furthermore, the private sector accounts for about about one third of 
the classes 6-8 enrollment in Sindh, of whom almost all come from urban areas and families with 
income above the median. The public sector school system accounts for about two thirds of class 
6-8 enrollment mostly from small towns and villages, where children come from poor families. The 
public elementary school system is pro-poor because it meets the needs of the poor in rural 
communities. In the absence of private girls schools in rural areas, girls must rely on the public 
system for education. It is understaffed due to difficulties in providing class 1-8 schools in rural 
communities, where attitudes toward education, especially for girls, are often not conducive to 
school attendance. In Sindh, inequities between the public and private elementary system mirror 
the general inequities between rural and urban households. Because of the low quality of public 
schooling,  many  students  from  poor  families  are  gravitating  towards  the  madrasahs,  where 
education is often narrowly focused on religious studies to the exclusion of broader subjects. 
 
4.  Based  on  an  analysis  of  household  surveys  and  social  impact  assessments,  Sindh 
requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to help accelerate the expansion of class 1-8 
elementary education to meet the Millennium Goals to provide a strong foundation for pro-poor 
economic  recovery  and  poverty  reduction.  Sindh  wishes  to  follow  the  example  of  Punjab 
Province,  which  already  provides  public  elementary  education.  With  only  about  38%  of

B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
 
5.  Class 1-8 elementary education in Sindh faces several major constraints. Administrative 
capacity has traditionally been weak and poorly financed, giving priority to classes 1-5 primary 
schools. Social service delivery has been inefficient, top down, and lacking local control. Under 
the devolution of powers to districts that occurred in August 2001, various levels of government 
including districts, subdistricts and union councils have had their staff increased and provided 
with general training in the new rules and procedures. Administration and funding decisions have 
been delegated so that communities and schools have more autonomy in prioritizing needs. 
Nongovernment  organizations  (NGOs),  community  volunteers,  and  school  management 
committees (SMCs) have been given more leeway to work as stakeholders to strengthen schools. 
Institutional reforms under devolution have given authority to elected officials in combination with 
strengthening of SMCs and school development funds (SDFs) through revised guidelines for 
staffing assignments, auditing, and planning. An example of local delegation of decision making 
includes training in planning and monitoring of school improvement so that rehabilitation and 
upgrading primary to elementary schools can be made based on need (Appendix 2).  
 
6.  Under SAP, multisector approaches to education policy planning and budgeting took 
shape for the first time. From this approach, the federal and provincial governments along with 
external aid agencies began developing sector-wide approaches employing annual operational 
plans and data collection from educational management information systems in each province. 
ADB is contributing to these efforts by focusing on Sindh province, where external assistance is 
weak but where the need is great and government commitment is high. This has led to looking at 
a long-term strategy to rationalize assistance under the newly emerging devolved social service 
delivery  with  emphasis  on  the  elementary  school  subsector.  The  process  approach  to  the 
subsector supports the Millennium Goals of universal elementary education by 2015. It goes hand 
in hand with the implementation of devolution, as ADB is reinforcing district education plans for 
the subsector that will yield a performance-based monitoring of school facilities, staffing, and 
resources tied to growth in school enrollments. ADB assistance to Sindh will be shared with other 
provinces and with other aid agencies working in other subsectors, so lessons learned will get 
disseminated widely. The investment project fits well with the wider aims of devolution and with 
the subsector-wide efforts of ADB and other agencies to strengthen citizens' boards and district 
level management including ombudsmen and to provide checks and balances between elected 
officials, NGOs, and school beneficiaries. 
 
7.  Finally, performance-based monitoring of the education system needs to more closely link 
community awareness of school relevance to school enrollment drives. Sindh has an educational 
database,  but  it  does  not  disaggregate  enrollments  for  the  elementary  school  sector  or 
disaggregate growth by district. Furthermore, inputs are not compared with outputs, so system 
efficiency cannot be measured. ADB efforts to rationalize the elementary school system will help 
to document school improvement in a cost-effective manner so that district education plans can 
be developed and targets measured. This will help to determine the precise staffing requirements 
based on school demand, and will also allow educators to determine the effect of interventions 
such as school stipends on enrollment growth, especially for female students in classes 6-8.

8.  The government strategy of both Pakistan and Sindh Province are designed to link basic 
education to poverty reduction, especially through the Education for All targets set by UNESCO2 
and subscribed to by the governments. Under the Interim Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper,3 the 
Federal Government has linked poverty reduction to elementary education through social capital 
creation to sustain good citizenship, job creation, consumer information, and reproductive health. 
The federal and provincial governments have initiated the Education Sector Reform4  (ESR) 
Action Program, which aims to raise gross enrollments as well as expand primary to elementary 
education. The ESR is the Government’s education policy and includes elementary education, 
madrassah  education,  and  support  for  district  education  offices  and  SMCs.  Development 
expenditure gaps identified under the ESR will be funded by external grants and through this 
project  in  the  form  of  development  funds  for  innovative  programs  such  as  preprimary 
(kindergarten)  and  elementary  education,  and  community  mobilization  through  school 
development  funds.  The  Project  will  strengthen  ongoing  programs  to  support  local  teacher 
recruitment and training, facilities and equipment upgrading, and district planning.  
 
9.  The Government already has initiated its Devolution of Power5 plan for local government, 
which  is  expected  to  fundamentally  alter  the  way  educational  service  delivery  is  provided 
(Appendix 3). Devolution supports governance through greater transparency, an increase in the 
number  of  stakeholders,  greater  accountability  including  financial  auditing,  and  civil  service 
reform devolving more staff to the local level. The Project will strengthen many of these goals 
through provision of additional funds and training to increase stakeholder participation and to 
raise the level of educational services to meet stakeholder expectations. Equally important, the 
Project will support institutional strengthening at the provincial, district, and subdistrict levels 
through  needs-based  provision  of  development  funds  for  elementary  education  targeted  for 
communities. The Government of Sindh has initiated major financial reforms to strengthen social 
service financing through increased provincial allocations, fiscal restructuring, federal support, 
support of the international community and public-private partnerships. Fiscal restructuring has 
eliminated the need for debt servicing and has freed up funds to support education and health 
reform in the province. 
 
10.  A  major  lesson  learned  from  past  involvement  in  education  in  Pakistan  and  Sindh 
concerns differentiating between macro policy planning versus micro-level project activities that 
provide hands-on implementation experience. During SAP, multisector policies for all provinces 
were pursued. While SAP made progress in coordinating these policies across provinces and 
sectors, it became clear that local implementation of these policies including institution building 
was met primarily through large provincial education investment projects by ADB and the World 
Bank. Consequently, both investment and program loans work best together to affect change in 
education.  Another  lesson  learned  is  that  recurrent  costs  for  new  staff  are  important  for 
sustainability. Previously the Government imposed recruitment bans for project school staff, 
which  eventually  jeopardized  project  effectiveness.  To  strengthen  sustainability,  covenants 
seeking compliance on staffing are stressed as well as provision of support mechanisms under 
the Project to ease the burden of incremental recurrent cost during project implementation. The 
Project  Performance  Audit  Report  (PPAR)  for  the  Primary  Girls  Education  (Sector)  Project6 
recommended that teacher deployment be closely linked with enrollments to improve internal 
efficiency in primary schools. The link between teacher deployment and student enrollment is 
central to building the elementary school system in Sindh. The Project will address this linkage

11.  The  ADB  poverty  reduction  strategy  supports  pro-poor  growth  through  social  capital

participated under previous SAP programs and continue to support education through the ESR 
and Education for All programs led by the Federal Ministry of Education employing a partial

12.  Major external technical assistance to education in Sindh consists of macro- and micro-
level approaches that support the Project. The World Bank plans a Provincial Adjustment Credit

B.  Components and Outputs 
 
15.  The Project has four components that support (i) school access, (ii) programs for female 
students, (iii) school quality improvements, and (iv) capacity building at the district offices. 
 
  1.  School Access 
 
16.  The first component builds access, especially for girls in rural areas, through needs-based 
assessment  among  the  community,  teachers  and  school  administrators.  Outputs  include 
(i) rehabilitation and upgrade of 1,200 primary to elementary schools (65% female schools) to 
increase enrollments of the age cohort from 38% to 55% (25% to 45% for females) through 
dropout prevention and classroom efficiency for classes 6-8; (ii) establishment of two English 
Medium Model Schools (one for boys/one for girls) in each of 102 subdistricts; (iii) establishment 
of 1,000 preprimary classes in selective elementary schools (50% female) to promote age-class 
standardization and encourage enrollment of the young to improve socialization skills and raise 
awareness of the importance of education; and (iv) conversion of 100 existing shelterless primary 
schools to elementary schools through community support and participation.  
 
17.  Key activities include mobilization of SMCs and subdistrict education administrators to 
identify needs-based priorities for schools (e.g., separate toilets for male and female students and 
staff,  sitting  room  for  female  teachers,  additional  classrooms,  boundary  wall,  water  pump,

education.  These  school  action  plans  will  be  tied  to  enrollment  projection  awareness  and 
strategies to ensure that facilities are tied to enrollment growth. Other activities include district 
level education planning to ensure that the network of elementary schools covers each district 
and provincial monitoring to ensure that the public elementary system is adequately staffed and 
equitably serves the entire province.

C.  Special Features 
 
28.  The Project includes a number of special features new to education in Sindh Province. 
Many of these features have resulted from experimentation in the past on a small scale, while 
others have resulted from recent institutional changes such as decentralization and emphasis on 
poverty reduction. Special features include the following: 
 
(i)  Decentralized school administration. The Government of Pakistan and all the 
provinces have initiated devolution of power sharing to the districts and below. 
Starting in August 2001, the process is under way and represents a major attempt 
at institutional devolution of power to the local elected officials with the expectation 
that local decision making and authority will lead to greater local accountability and 
efficiency  in  social  service  delivery.  In  education,  prospects  for  spending 
prioritization and deployment of teachers on contract and accountable to local 
officials will improve school performance. The Project will support this process by 
providing  development  funds  through  the  districts  based  on  local  needs 
assessment  and  will  lead  to  greater  efficiency  in  ensuring  that  resources  are 
utilized  where  they  are  needed.  Under  the  Project,  a  performance-based 
management  system  will  be  implemented  at  the  district  level  to  monitor  the 
equitable distribution of educational resources within the district along with the 
enrollment  and  attendance  outcomes  on  which  the  resources  get  distributed. 
(Component 3) 
 
(ii)  Revolving funds. Under the Project, SDF accounts will be used to channel up to 
$1,000 each to SMCs for a host of innovative programs designed to improve 
school  performance.  The  concept  that  local  control  of  resources  for  school 
improvements is the basis for bottom-up changes in quality will be tested through 
the use of the SDF. The SDF builds on the existing SMC school account started 
under SAP but will expand the kinds of support from simple nonschool salary items 
such as chalk and maintenance to matching funds and incentives for student 
attendance, to stipends for girls and free textbooks, to scholarships for female 
teacher candidates. These programs will be administered through the SMC for 
amounts  of  about  $1,000  per  school  (excluding  civil  works)  needed  to  fully 
establish elementary schools. Funds will be provided based on a formula that 
rewards  school  attendance,  enrollment  growth,  and  dropout  reduction.  The 
provincial  project  accounts  officer  will  monitor  the  disbursements  and 
replenishments based on receipts provided by each SMC, and each SDF will be 
audited annually according to Government regulations. (Component 2)

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 
 
46.  Sindh wants to develop economically and socially by reducing poverty and raising its 
human resource base so that rural areas can benefit from economic activity generated in Karachi, 
Hyderabad, and Nawabshah. To accomplish this, Sindh must raise the province’s education level 
from the class 1-5 primary school system to a class 1-8 elementary school system. The Project 
will support all existing 2,000 class 1-8 public elementary schools and provide upgrading from 
primary to elementary for an additional 1,400 selected schools, especially in rural areas (65% 
female) leading to a province-wide public elementary system that will eventually serve 55% of all 
eligible 10-12 year olds. Consequently, about 500,000 existing class 6-8 public school students 
will  benefit  from  the  project  along  with  an  additional  168,000  students  who  will  have  the 
opportunity to attend classes 6-8 for a total of 668,000 students enrolled annually in classes 6-8 
by 2009. In addition, the Project will provide faculties, furniture, equipment, learning materials, 
and  training  to  200,000  class  1-5  students  in  1,400  project  schools.  Under  the  program, 
approximately  1,000  schools  will  commence  preprimary  classes  for  approximately  30,000

16  
preschoolers (50% female). Selected madrasah schools will be provided teacher training in class 
6-8 core subjects. 
 
47.  Approximately  5,000  new  teachers  (65%  female)  serving  in  elementary  schools  will 
benefit from the Project through academic and administrative training. About 4,000 education 
supervisors and administrators and 10,000 parents and community leaders will benefit from 
training  in  school-community  mobilization.  These  beneficiaries  will  provide  the  impetus  for 
strengthening and expanding the elementary school system in Sindh, especially in rural areas. 
Indirect beneficiaries include the labor required to upgrade and rehabilitate schools and build 
furniture, book distributors, employment for about 5,000 new teachers in rural areas over 9 years, 
local hiring of community workers in the area of life skills training, and preprimary education and 
teacher aides. Local NGOs and technical experts will also benefit by providing leadership training 
and  technology  transfer  in  rural  areas,  and  about  3,000  women  will  benefit  from  teaching 
scholarships  and  about  75,000  class  6-8  girls  will  receive  annual  stipends  through  school 
subsidizes to reduce dropout and increase retention rates. 
 
48.  The Project will provide substantial beneficial impacts. It will enable Sindh to establish and 
operate province-wide pro-poor public class 1-8 elementary schools serving students in rural and 
poor  areas.  The  elementary  system  will  be  based  on  surveys  rationalizing  school  facilities, 
staffing, and budgeting of approximately 3,400 elementary schools. The impact of a province-
wide public elementary school system will raise the level of education in the province and reduce 
the gap between the urban and rural, male and female enrollments.  It will also reduce the gap 
between the public and the private elementary school system in the province. The Project will 
offer parents and students a low-cost accessible system of public education in rural areas through 
class 8. Class 8 is considered to be the minimum level of education needed to ensure sustainable 
cognitive  skills  and  knowledge  needed  in  a  modern  economy.  Social  externalities  include 
promotion of health and population welfare for future mothers, good citizenship, and efficient 
consumerism required for effective social living. Furthermore, an elementary school system built 
on community participation and decentralized decision making is likely to increase the demand for 
education based on need and to stimulate social welfare in the form of participatory democracy 
and understanding of the importance of education for improving the quality of life (Appendix 11).  
 
49.  The impact of the Project on the education system is expected to be great. First, the 
Project supports the shift to decentralized management of educational services to the district level 
and below, where management and budgeting will lead to operational decisions taken close to 
the user. Decentralization brings together elected district officials and citizens to decide on school 
priorities  throughout  the  district.  Under  devolution,  educational  decision  making  and  data 
collection at the subdistrict level will be strengthened through additional facilities, staff, and 
budget resources to monitor individual school staff and SMCs. The Project will support activities 
that allow local decisions to prioritize educational needs taken within schools and communities to 
find  their  way  to  the  district  for  approval.  Efforts  to  involve  parents  through  SMCs  and 
communities  through  citizens'  boards  will  have  a  positive  impact  in  support  of  devolution. 
Likewise, the Project will enable the SDFs managed by SMCs to be strengthened and expanded 
to cover selected school improvement activities managed by parents and teachers that lead to 
greater accountability of the community in taking responsibility for the education of their children. 
Finally, at the provincial level, the project impact will be to strengthen the role of the province 
under devolution to monitor inputs and outputs across districts in the province.  
 
50.  At the school level, the project impact will help to ensure that quality improvements to 
elementary  education  are  based  on  need,  leading  to  improvements  in  school  attendance, 
completion rates and dropout reduction throughout classes 1-8. The introduction of preprimary 
education  designed  around  socialization  skills  will  help  to  encourage  positive  attitudes  of

17
preschoolers once they enter class 1, which will lead to lower dropout and improved learning 
readiness  among  first  graders.  The  Project  will  impact  school-community  relations  through 
mobilization of the SMCs linked to the principals and to the school supervisors at the union 
council and subdistrict education offices. This participatory approach has often been lacking and 
has  been  partly  responsible  for  the  top-down  approach,  which  lacked  ownership  within  the 
community.  The  innovative  attempts  to  strengthen  the  SDF  through  small  grants  rewarding 
school performance, especially through student and teacher attendance, is another impact that 
will strengthen the quality of elementary education in Sindh.  
 
51.  Girls are underrepresented in elementary education for economic and social reasons. 
Girls will attend school if classes 6-8 are available not too far from home. This is the major 
problem preventing female enrollments from rising above 30%. Issues of opportunity costs, child 
labor, and cultural norms dictating little education for females will always be a problem, but the 
project focus will be on getting the first 50% of girls into school. Recurrent costs for stipends and 
free textbooks will be implemented for all class 6-8 females as a result of the Project. The Project 
will prepare a gender strategy to mainstream girls elementary education in Sindh.  
 
52.  Ethnic minorities such as Hindu, Christian, and Sikh are small in number but may be 
congregated  in  some  districts  more  than  others.  In  some  cases,  local  language  sensitivity 
prevents minorities from doing well in school. The Government has a policy of mainstreaming 
minorities and second language learners. In such cases, learning materials and training prepared 
under the Project will be automatically provided in the Urdu and Sindi languages, and the PIU will 
request technical experts to offer guidelines to district officials to ensure mainstreaming of all 
children into the formal education system. 
 
53.  Likely risks in implementing the Project in Sindh Province are well known from past 
projects and from the many aid agency reports and government studies commissioned to make 
recommendations. However, the integrated benefits and impacts far outweigh the costs given 
these risks (Appendix 12). 
 
A.  Financial Risk 
54.  The main financial risk is the potential inability of each district to sustain recurrent funds 
for the salaries of new teachers to be deployed in project schools in classes 6-8. Federal, 
provincial, and district officers negotiate budgets annually. The Project provides for incremental 
recurrent costs to support the process of teacher deployment during project implementation. 
However,  recurrent  funds  for  teacher  salaries  made  after  project  completion  represent  a 
continuous  charge  to  the  provincial  finance  department.  World  Bank  and  ADB  program 
adjustment credits will help to ensure increased social sector budgets based on policies to 
support education over the long term. The financial analysis of the province’s education budget 
revealed that the recurrent costs under the Project represent a small increase in the overall 
allocation for staffing when averaged over 6 years of project implementation and another 3 years 
after project completion as project staff are fully utilized. Covenants are provided to ensure that 
adequate staff budgets for project schools are provided. The need for accurate financial data to 
budget the public elementary school system requires a comprehensive survey that looks at the 
facilities, enrollments, staffing and budgeting of elementary schools. The survey to be carried out 
under the Project will serve as the baseline and help to develop the enrollment projection system 
to  measure  progress.  Budgets  for  stipends  and  free  textbooks  for  classes  6-8  girls  will  be 
required after project completion, and assurances have been given that the policy of stipends and 
free textbooks for girls will be expanded to classes 6-8. The Federal and provincial governments 
have recently separated the auditor general and accountant general functions, which will help to 
ensure independent audits, especially at the district level under devolution. Likewise, under

18  
sector-wide  technical  assistance,14  consistent  budget  classification  systems  have  been 
introduced throughout the country to again improve compliance and monitoring.  
 
B.  Social Risk 
55.  Social targeting of the poor and females, especially in rural areas, may lead to abuse in 
allocating student stipends and teacher candidate scholarships by SMCs in some schools. SMC 
training by gender specialists in selection and monitoring procedures for these programs will be 
critical  for  success.  It  is  widely  acknowledged  that  full  participation  leading  to  a  full  need 
assessment will improve transparency, and this is why extensive training of SMC members, 
teachers, and local school administrators is essential to ensure that project funds are effectively 
utilized. Consequently, the main social risk includes the potential weakness of SMCs to mobilize 
female  teachers  to  serve  in  the  communities.  Under  devolution,  teacher  appointment  and 
deployment have been localized, and the Government will increase the budget for primary and 
elementary education. The Project provides for scholarships to young candidates along with 
additional funds to hire teacher aides from the community to assist in classroom activities. 
 
C.  Policy Risk 
56.  The main policy risk under the Project is the potential inability of each district to take 
action to fill gaps in the public elementary school system once recommendations from the project 
survey are known. Covenants have been included to ensure that action is taken on time and 
policy analysts provided. School-community mobilization will be key to building awareness and 
accountability into the system. It is labor intensive and requires a strong commitment to draw on 
continuous NGO/CBO expertise in communities and to build awareness and capacity among 
individual schools. The Project provides adequate funds for capacity building, but since mostly 
only NGO expertise is available to provide many of the activities, it is critical that district and 
provincial governments recognize the importance of NGO participation to build capacity.

1.  Social  sector  service  delivery  for  education  has  lagged  behind  targets  set  by  the 
Government for the past 10 years despite Social Action Program (SAP) policies to protect the 
level of social sector spending. Reasons for the poor performance include the global economic 
downturn, political developments in the region and a lack of management capacity needed to 
coordinate change. The Government of Sindh recognizes that a strong elementary school 
system  serving  the  majority  of  students  is  essential  to  raise  the  prospects  for  economic 
development, social mobility, education, and job opportunities to reduce poverty. For Sindh, 
public provision of educational services is essential to ensure an important public good, ensure 
equity across all the districts and correct market failures where the private education sector 
siphons off those with ability to pay. Sindh Province is especially at risk of not employing basic 
education to reduce poverty especially outside Karachi, where 65% of the 30 million Sindh 
population reside in underserved rural areas. Decentralization of public services is viewed as 
one way to help ensure that decisions are taken closest to those who benefit from education—
decisions that lead to long-term poverty reduction in communities (Figure A3.1). 
 
2.  The Sindh education system caters to 6.0 million children aged 5-10 (primary) and 
another  2.0  million  aged  11-13  (middle)  for  a  total  cohort  of  8  million  elementary  school 
students. At present about 65% of the primary school age cohort attend school while 38% of the 
middle school age group are enrolled. There is a small but high quality private elementary 
education system operating in urban areas, especially in Karachi, that serves the middle and 
upper classes. The private system caters to the upper 50% of income families and charges fees 
three to four times the amount charged to public school students. In contrast, the public school 
system is large but inefficiently organized and ineffectively operated. It serves rural areas where 
the population of school-going children is poor and scattered. Given the cultural impediments of 
meeting the needs of female students who are unable to travel long distances from home to 
school, girls’ education is especially underserved by the public school system. According to the 
Pakistan Household Survey, between 1997 and 1999 the Asian Crisis impacted on the gap 
between the urban and rural in terms of elementary school participation rates, with a lesser 
proportion of children from the lowest income households going to school as compared with 
previous years. However, while boys dropped out of school due to economic hardship, girls' 
enrollments actually grew. 
 
3.  The result of this two-tier elementary education system in Sindh is a private sector 
school system that attracts one in three parents who can afford to send children to schools 
possessing adequate facilities, staff and budgets. The public school system caters to two in 
three parents from the bottom 50% of the household income and those living in rural areas. The 
schools often lack facilities, staff, and adequate budgets, and students still must pay fees that 
can amount to $30 each year for books, uniforms, and incidentals, which is often prohibitive. 
Sindh wants to develop a rationalized system of elementary schools for classes1-8 throughout 
the province that will serve both rural and urban areas and will complement the private sector 
system. Until a majority of the young are in school through class 8, exposure to new ideas and 
ways of doing things will not take root (Table A3.1). 
 
4.  Based on enrollment projections, the Provincial Education Department estimates that an 
additional 250,000 students—two thirds of them girls—will complete class 5 in the coming 10 
years but will not be able to attend class 6 due to a shortage of available elementary schools in 
local communities. This number includes potential students who could be pulled into class 6 and 
beyond through upgrading primary schools to elementary schools. Along similar lines, estimates 
suggest that the internal efficiency of class 1-5 could be improved by 10% over the next 5 years 
to increase the number of class 5 public school leavers by 200,000, thereby contributing to the

5.  Reasons why education lags in rural Sindh are several. First, there has not been a 
concerted effort to map school enrollments, school locations and staff deployment throughout 
the  province.  The  educational  management  information  system  developed  under  the  SAP 
lacked the sophistication needed to collect statistics annually, and political interference from 
provincial politicians affected teacher assignments, which was not picked up in the surveys. 
Second,  teacher  deployment  was  not  accurately  reflected  in  data  collection  and,  more 
importantly, decisions on teacher assignment were not taken at the local level. Consequently, 
communities had no control over teacher assignment or performance. Third, incentive systems 
for both teachers and communities did not exist and so communities lacked the ability to reward 
teacher performance and encourage parents to send their children to school regularly.  
 
6.  Recognizing these failures, the Provincial Education Department has embarked on a 
program to map the existing 2,000 class 1-8 elementary schools to note location, coverage or 
catchment area, enrollments, and staff resources. Planning for expansion of schools with full 
classes  1-8  will  allow  unserved  communities  to  request  on  a  needs  basis  for  upgraded 
elementary schools. Efforts are under way to strengthen the local community through support 
for existing School Management Committees to make them important stakeholders in ensuring 
that schools function efficiently. The link between parents and community with local schools will 
be  critical  to  effective  networking  of  elementary  schools  in  Sindh  and  will  help  ensure 
community involvement to take decisions based on need to improve schools. For example, 
teacher attendance will be monitored by the staff management committee and reported to the 
union council. Further, deployment of new teachers will be made at the district and local levels 
and not at the provincial offices (Table A3.3). 
 
7.  The  Government  of  Sindh  views  poverty  reduction,  especially  among  the  rural 
population, as the key to boosting economic development outside of Karachi. Education plays 
an important role to create the social capital needed by the poor to reach their maximum 
potential. Sindh's poverty framework includes physical asset creation including access to credit, 
social asset creation including education and nutrition, social safety nets and good governance 
including devolution of power, civil service reforms, and access to justice. Education’s role in 
reducing poverty stems from providing opportunities for social and job mobility. Until a majority 
of the young are exposed to new ideas through schooling, it is unlikely that the population will 
have the skills and knowledge to escape poverty (Table A3.4).
